_comment: Created by EFisher on 26/03/2014 17:21:33 using v2.1
title: How does one-year cancer survival vary by cancer type?
analysis_commentary: The measure we use here is derived from cancer registry data and based on the estimated chance of surviving the cancer alone ( that is it excludes the underlying mortality rates for a person of that age/gender) . For more information about this measure, please see 'about this data' below. For the one-year estimated survival data, there is large variation between the cancer types. Pancreas, lung and oesophagus have the lowest one-year survival, with 19.6%, 32.9% and 42.0% respectively. The highest one-year survival estimates are breast (women only), melanoma of the skin and testis (men only); with 95.8%, 97.0% and 98.1% respectively.
data_source: Office for National Statistics, Cancer Survival in England
